content: The "Small Business Credit Availability Act" may be cited as the short title. Business Development Companies can own securities of investment advisers and certain financial companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission must codify regulations within a year of the Act's enactment. Failure to do so allows business development companies to proceed as if the regulations were completed. The Commission can still address conflicts of interest between business development companies and investment advisers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow certain securities to be considered permissible assets for business development companies, as long as they meet specific criteria. The total value of these securities cannot exceed 20 percent of the company's total assets. PARITY FOR BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT COMPANIES REGARDING OFFERING AND PROXY RULES. The Securities and Exchange Commission must revise rules within 1 year to allow business development companies to use securities offering and proxy rules available to other issuers under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. This includes revising rule 405 to remove the exclusion of business development companies from the definition of a well-known seasoned issuer. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules to allow business development companies to use securities offering and proxy rules available to other issuers. This includes removing exclusions for business development companies from various rules under the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules under the Securities Act of 1933 to include business development companies in various rules previously excluding them. This includes rules 138, 139, 164, 433, and 415. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules under the Securities Act of 1933 to include business development companies in various rules previously excluding them, such as rules 138, 139, 164, 433, and 415. Additionally, the Commission will make changes to rules 497, 172, and 173 to accommodate business development companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rules under the Securities Act of 1933 to include business development companies in various rules previously excluding them. This includes changes to rules 418, 14a-101, and 103 to provide exemptions and accommodations for business development companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission will revise rule 103 under Regulation FD to include business development companies in Form N-2, incorporating by reference reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Additionally, Form N-2 will be revised to allow well-known seasoned issuers to conduct automatic shelf offerings. A well-known seasoned issuer may file automatic shelf offerings on Form N-2. If the Commission fails to complete required revisions in a timely manner, a business development company can consider them completed until the Commission finishes them. Any reference to a rule or form in this section includes the rule or form and any successor.
